questions.question: What is the main purpose of conceptual database design?
questions.option_a: A. To implement SQL queries directly
questions.option_b: B. To create a high-level schema based on user requirements
questions.option_d: D. To define access rights for users
questions.explanation: Conceptual database design creates a high-level schema (ER model) from user requirements before physical implementation.

questions.question: Which of the following best represents an entity in ER modeling?
questions.option_a: A. A relationship between two tables
questions.option_b: B. A noun or noun phrase representing a real-world object
questions.option_d: D. A primary key of a relation
questions.explanation: Entities represent real-world objects, typically named with nouns or noun phrases such as Student or Employee.

questions.question: Which ER symbol is used to represent a weak entity?
questions.explanation: Weak entities are represented by double-lined rectangles in ER diagrams.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a composite attribute?
questions.option_c: C. Name consisting of First, Middle, and Last name
questions.explanation: Composite attributes can be divided into subparts, such as Name into First, Middle, and Last.

questions.question: What type of attribute is represented using a dotted oval in ER diagrams?
questions.explanation: Derived attributes, such as Age (from DOB), are shown using a dotted oval.

questions.question: Which attribute type allows multiple values for a single entity instance?
questions.explanation: Multivalued attributes, such as multiple email addresses, allow more than one value for a single entity.

questions.question: What is the minimal set of attributes that uniquely identifies an entity?
questions.explanation: Candidate keys are minimal sets of attributes that uniquely identify an entity.

questions.question: Which key type may consist of multiple attributes together?
questions.explanation: Composite keys consist of multiple attributes used together to uniquely identify records.

questions.question: What does a relationship represent in ER modeling?
questions.option_a: A. An attribute between two entities
questions.option_b: B. An association among two or more entities
questions.explanation: Relationships capture associations between entities, such as Student–Enrolls–Course.

questions.question: A ternary relationship involves how many entities?
questions.explanation: A ternary relationship involves exactly three entities.

questions.question: Which cardinality ratio represents many-to-many relationships?
questions.explanation: N:M specifies that many entities in one set relate to many entities in another set.

questions.question: Which relationship type is represented when an employee manages exactly one department and each department has only one manager?
questions.explanation: This is a one-to-one relationship where one employee manages one department.

questions.question: Which type of relationship describes an employee working in one department while a department can have many employees?
questions.explanation: This is a one-to-many relationship: one department can have many employees.

questions.question: Which relationship type represents an employee working on several projects, with projects having multiple employees?
questions.explanation: Many-to-many relationships occur when both sides can have multiple associations.

questions.question: What is a recursive relationship?
questions.option_a: A. A relationship involving more than three entities
questions.option_b: B. A relationship where an entity is related to itself
questions.option_c: C. A relationship involving weak entities
questions.option_d: D. A relationship with descriptive attributes
questions.explanation: Recursive relationships occur when the same entity participates more than once in different roles, e.g., Employee supervises Employee.

questions.question: Which type of attribute describes information about a relationship rather than entities?
questions.explanation: Descriptive attributes store information about relationships, e.g., 'since' in WorksIn(Employee, Department).

questions.question: What does total participation mean in ER modeling?
questions.option_a: A. All entities in one set must participate in the relationship
questions.option_b: B. At least one entity must participate in the relationship
questions.option_c: C. No entities participate in the relationship
questions.explanation: Total participation means every entity in one set must participate in the relationship (double lines).

questions.question: Which ER construct is represented by double lines between an entity and a relationship?
questions.explanation: Double lines from entity to relationship denote total participation.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about weak entities?
questions.option_a: A. They have their own primary key independent of other entities
questions.option_b: B. They rely on an identifying relationship with a strong entity
questions.explanation: Weak entities depend on a strong entity for identification and exist through identifying relationships.

questions.question: What is a partial key?
questions.option_a: A. A subset of attributes forming part of the key of a weak entity
questions.option_b: B. A candidate key that is not minimal
questions.option_c: C. A key attribute of a composite key
questions.explanation: Partial keys are attributes of weak entities that combine with the strong entity’s key for unique identification.

questions.question: In ER diagrams, what symbol is used to represent an ISA relationship?
questions.explanation: ISA (specialization/generalization) relationships are represented using a triangle.

questions.question: Specialization in ER modeling refers to:
questions.option_a: A. Combining entities into a supertype
questions.option_b: B. Splitting an entity into subtypes based on distinguishing characteristics
questions.explanation: Specialization divides an entity into subtypes with additional attributes or relationships.

questions.question: Generalization in ER modeling refers to:
questions.option_a: A. Combining multiple entities into a supertype
questions.explanation: Generalization abstracts common features of multiple entities into a supertype.

questions.question: Which constraint ensures that an entity belongs to exactly one of its subclasses?
questions.explanation: Disjoint constraint ensures entities cannot belong to more than one subclass simultaneously.

questions.question: If an employee can be both a permanent and contract employee, which subclass constraint applies?
questions.explanation: Overlapping allows an entity to belong to multiple subclasses simultaneously.

questions.question: When every entity of a supertype must belong to at least one of its subtypes, it is called:
questions.explanation: Total specialization (covering constraint) requires all supertype entities to belong to a subtype.

questions.question: If not all supertype entities are required to be in a subtype, what is this called?
questions.explanation: Partial specialization allows some entities of a supertype not to belong to any subtype.

questions.question: Which type of specialization occurs when subclasses collectively cover all entities in the super class?
questions.explanation: Total specialization means all supertype entities are covered by subtypes.

questions.question: Which example illustrates a recursive relationship in a university ER model?
questions.explanation: Recursive relationship occurs when entities of the same type relate, e.g., Student supervises Student.
